content.title: Understanding Series Circuits
content.content:
A **series circuit** is the simplest way to connect electrical components. In this configuration, all components are connected end-to-end, forming a **single continuous loop**. This means there is only one path for the electrons to travel from the negative terminal of the source to the positive terminal.

### The Golden Rules of Series Circuits

To master series circuits, you must understand three core rules regarding current, voltage, and resistance:

1. **Current (I) is the same everywhere:** Because there is only one path, the number of electrons flowing past any point in the circuit per second is identical. If you place an ammeter anywhere in the loop, the reading will be the same. Formula: It = I1 = I2 = I3.

2. **Total Resistance (Rt) is the sum of all parts:** Every component added in series adds more "friction" or opposition to the flow. To find the total resistance, you simply add the individual values together. Formula: Rt = R1 + R2 + R3...

3. **Voltage (V) is shared:** The total supply voltage is divided among the components based on their resistance. A higher resistance component will take a larger share of the voltage (a larger voltage drop). The sum of these drops always equals the supply voltage. Formula: Vt = V1 + V2 + V3...

### The Water Analogy
Imagine a single loop of pipe filled with water, with a pump (the battery) and several narrow sections (resistors). Because it is one continuous loop, the water cannot "disappear"; it must flow at the same speed through every part of the pipe. If you add more narrow sections, the overall flow slows down (resistance increases). If you break the pipe at any point, the entire flow stops immediately.

### Real-World Applications and Limitations
Series circuits are common in **control circuits**, such as an emergency stop button connected in series with a motor contactor. If the button is pressed, the circuit breaks and the motor stops. However, they are rarely used for domestic lighting or sockets. Why? Because if one bulb blows in a series string (like old Christmas lights), the circuit is broken and **every light goes out**. Furthermore, every time you add a bulb, they would all get dimmer because the voltage is being shared between more components.

questions.questionText: How many paths for current flow exist in a series circuit?
questions.hint: Think about the definition of a single loop.

questions.questionText: If an ammeter at the start of a series circuit reads 5A, what will an ammeter at the end read?
questions.hint: Remember the rule for current in a single path.

questions.questionText: What happens to the total resistance if you add another resistor to a series circuit?
questions.hint: You are adding more opposition to the same single path.

questions.questionText: Why does a break in one component cause the entire series circuit to stop working?
questions.expectedAnswer: Because there is only one path for current, so a break anywhere stops the flow everywhere.
questions.hint: Relate the number of paths to the concept of continuity.

content.title: Worked Example: Calculating a Series Circuit
content.given: A 12V DC battery is connected in series with two resistors: R1 = 4Ω and R2 = 2Ω.

steps.description: Calculate the total resistance (Rt) of the circuit.
Calculate the total current (It) flowing through the circuit using Ohm's Law.
State the current flowing through resistor R1.

content.notes: Always find total resistance first before trying to find the circuit current.

content.title: Guided Practice (We Do)
content.problem: A circuit has a 24V supply and three resistors connected in series, each with a resistance of 4Ω.

steps.prompt: First, calculate the total resistance (Rt). What is the sum of 4Ω + 4Ω + 4Ω?
Now use Ohm's Law (I = V / R) to find the total current. What is 24V divided by your Rt?
steps.hint: Divide the supply voltage (24) by the total resistance you just found.

questions.questionText: Find the total resistance of a series circuit containing three resistors: 10Ω, 20Ω, and 30Ω.
A 100V supply is connected to a series circuit with a total resistance of 50Ω. What is the current?
If a series circuit has a constant current of 3A, how much current flows through the fourth resistor in the chain?
questions.hint: Remember the current rule for series circuits.

questions.questionText: Explain why an electrician would connect multiple safety switches in series rather than parallel to protect a machine, and describe what happens to the circuit current if any one switch is opened.
questions.expectedAnswer: Safety switches are in series so that any single switch can break the only path for current. If any switch opens, the circuit is broken, and the current drops to zero immediately, stopping the machine.
questions.hint: Think about the 'single path' rule and how it affects the flow if that path is interrupted.
